reinforcements.existing_element_id: works-001 (System 1 Trust Gate at Every Phase Transition)
reinforcements.similarity: Both address the weekly stay cycle as a critical recurring touchpoint. The existing element prescribes passing System 1's automatic assessment at every phase transition. The new element (Weekly Stay Cycle as Hook Loop) prescribes designing the active lease as a series of weekly hook cycles. Both recognize that the Stays Manager is the foundational architecture for guest engagement.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence: each phase transition must signal continuity. New evidence: the weekly stay cycle IS a series of phase transitions (arrive → stay → depart → review → prepare for next). Both use cognitive fluency as the theoretical basis — the existing element via Kahneman's associative coherence, the new element via Eyal's Hook Model. Combined insight: the weekly stay cycle is both a hook cycle AND a series of micro-phase-transitions, each requiring System 1 approval.

reinforcements.existing_element_id: works-003 (Match Platform Speed to Conversational Speed)
reinforcements.similarity: Both address the gap between human-mediated interaction speed and platform interaction speed. The existing element prescribes matching the platform's cognitive speed to the phone call. The new element (Self-Service Flexibility Expression) prescribes making day-of-week flexibility expression faster on the platform than during a phone call. Both use the same benchmark: if the guest can express it verbally in N seconds, the platform must capture it in under 1.5N seconds.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence: Andreas describes two units in 7 seconds of speech. New evidence: Tyler negotiates day flexibility over 10 minutes of back-and-forth. The flexibility selector should reduce this to 30 seconds. Both cite Eyal/Kahneman on the law of least effort. The combined insight: platform interactions must be faster than conversation for both SIMPLE information (unit descriptions) and COMPLEX information (day-of-week flexibility patterns).

reinforcements.existing_element_id: works-004 (Bridge Human Trust to Digital Trust)
reinforcements.similarity: Both address the problem of data and trust being held by a human agent rather than the platform. The existing element prescribes bridging human trust to digital trust through continuity priming. The new element (Guest Investment Capture at First Contact) prescribes capturing the guest's investment data in the platform at first contact instead of in the agent's notes.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence: the agent promises email exchange and follow-up, but the platform is never mentioned. New evidence: Tyler provides all his requirements to the agent but the platform stores none of them. Both recognize the same structural problem: the agent IS the platform from the user's perspective. Combined insight: the bridge must be bi-directional — trust flows from human to platform AND data flows from conversation to database.

reinforcements.existing_element_id: guest-works-004 (from nneka run: Eliminate Off-Platform Communication)
reinforcements.similarity: Both address external-to-internal trigger migration. The existing guest element from the nneka run prescribes eliminating off-platform communication by making the platform faster than texting. The new element prescribes a trigger migration pathway from agent-dependency to platform-dependency. Both use Eyal's trigger theory as the theoretical basis.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence: Brad texts Nneka to reschedule because texting is faster than the platform. New evidence: Tyler's only trigger is the agent's phone call — zero platform triggers established. Combined insight: trigger migration must address TWO failure modes — (1) the guest texting the host instead of using the platform (nneka run), and (2) the guest depending on the agent instead of the platform (Tyler run). The platform must be faster than both texting AND calling.

reinforcements.existing_element_id: guest-works-003 (from nneka run: Stays Manager as System 1 Dashboard)
reinforcements.similarity: Both prescribe restructuring the active lease view to prioritize next-action over full-calendar display. The existing element recommends the Stays Manager as a System 1 dashboard with minimal cognitive load. The new element specifies the information hierarchy: next action → upcoming exceptions → history → full calendar.
reinforcements.combined_evidence: Library evidence: Stays Manager is the most-visited page (13+ visits per lease). New evidence: Tyler's weekly pattern with holiday exceptions requires a next-action-first dashboard. Combined insight: the dashboard must serve both regular weekly check-ins (the norm) and exception management (holidays, travel) without overloading cognitive capacity.

contradictions.conflict: The new element recommends #31135D (primary-purple) for selected day chips. The existing style guide uses --chat-purple (rgb(75,71,206)) for active day badges. These are different purples with different color temperatures.
contradictions.evidence_comparison: The new element aligns with the proposed Paula Scher recommendations to consolidate day badges under brand purple and eliminate chat-purple. The existing style guide is production CSS. Recommendation: follow Paula Scher's proposal to align day badges with brand purple, but note this requires a production CSS change.
contradictions.recommendation: Follow the new element's color recommendation (#31135D for selected state) as it aligns with the proposed color consolidation. Update --chat-purple references to --primary-purple in day badge components.

extensions.gap_filled: The library has no element specifically addressing how guests express day-of-week flexibility through self-service. Previous runs focused on host-side listing creation and guest-side Stays Manager. This is the first element targeting the guest search-to-proposal flexibility expression pattern.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens (Tyler Wood + Hooked), but strongly supported by the call evidence. Tyler spent 10+ minutes on flexibility negotiation that should take 30 seconds on the platform. High confidence this is a real gap.

extensions.gap_filled: The library has pricing-related elements for the host side (how hosts set prices) but no element addressing how guests perceive and evaluate day-based pricing. This is the first element targeting guest-side price transparency for the nights-of-the-week model.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens, but Tyler's explicit concern about price manipulation ('don't push up the price') is strong evidence. The Hook Model's autonomy principle reinforces the design direction.

extensions.gap_filled: The library has elements about human-to-digital handoff (trust bridging from agent to platform) but no element specifically addressing the external-marketplace-to-platform bridge (Craigslist → Split Lease). This is the first element targeting guests who discover Split Lease through external listing aggregators.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens. Tyler's discovery path may not be representative of all guests, but Craigslist cross-posting is a known acquisition channel for Split Lease. Medium confidence — needs validation with more guest calls.

extensions.gap_filled: The library has no element addressing the emotional design of the self-cleaning reciprocal arrangement. This is unique to the shared space model and critical for weekly stay guests who exchange cleaning duties.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens. Tyler's call explicitly discusses self-cleaning as a cost-saving option. The Hook Model's reward-of-the-self framework provides a strong theoretical basis for reframing cleaning as pride. Medium-high confidence.

extensions.gap_filled: The library has no element addressing the emotional design of the gap between intake and match delivery. This is a critical dropout zone where guest enthusiasm decays without reinforcement.
extensions.confidence_note: Single lens, but the pattern is universal: any guest whose first contact is agent-mediated will experience a waiting period. The Hook Model's trigger theory strongly supports the need for owned triggers during this gap. High confidence.

new_tokens_flagged: --day-chip-flexible-bg: rgba(49, 19, 93, 0.08) — proposed in looks-001 for the flexible/outline state of day chips
--stay-card-gradient: linear-gradient(135deg, rgb(252,250,255) 0%, #F7F2FA 100%) — proposed in looks-003 for warm stay card background
token_compliance.recommendation: Add both tokens to the design system. The day-chip-flexible-bg is a functional token needed for the three-state day selector (selected/flexible/available). The stay-card-gradient is a semantic token for the active lease dashboard. Both align with the existing purple palette and off-white background system.

arc_conflicts: The negotiation phase targets 'confidence' but the waiting period between call and match delivery targets 'calm.' These are compatible but the transition needs care — the guest goes from active engagement (confidence) to passive waiting (calm) and back to active engagement (confidence at acceptance). The calm-during-waiting must not decay into apathy.
emotional_arc_check.arc_assessment: The emotional arc follows a coherent progression: curiosity → confidence → excitement → calm → belonging → pride. The arc builds from uncertainty to ownership. The main risk is the waiting period (between search and match) where the arc dips into passive calm. The waiting period anxiety management element (feels-004) addresses this by maintaining engagement signals. Overall, the arc is sound and aligns with both the Hook Model's trigger-action-reward-investment cycle and the guest journey's progression from stranger to resident.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: The acceptance phase has only 1 element (journey-context mention). Layer 1 should produce at least one process pattern for the acceptance moment — the Hook Model's reward phase is strongest here but no Layer 1 element specifically addresses the reward design of acceptance.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Consider the acceptance moment as the Variable Reward payoff in the Hook Model. What should the guest experience when the host accepts their proposal? This is the moment where uncertainty resolves to certainty — the strongest emotional opportunity in the funnel.

loop_back_recommendations.reason: The move_in phase has a strong emotional element (belonging) but no explicit tension-relief design for the moment the guest first enters the physical space. This is the highest-stakes reality-check moment.
loop_back_recommendations.new_input: Consider the first physical entry: the guest has only seen photos/virtual tour. How should the platform manage the emotional transition from digital expectation to physical reality? What if the space doesn't match?
